sections.content: দ্য প্রোফেট হচ্ছে লেবাননী-আমেরিকান কবি, চিত্রশিল্পী, লেখক, দার্শনিক, ধর্মতত্ত্ববিদ, চাক্ষুষ শিল্পী কাহলিল জিবরানের লিখা ২৬টি গদ্য কবিতার একটি বই যা ইংরেজিতে লিখা হয়েছে।"Prophet Motive", Joan Acocella এটি ১৯২৩ সালে মূলত আলফ্রেড এ. নফ প্রকাশ করে। এটি জিবরানের পরিচিত সেরা কাজ। প্রোফেট বইটি ৮০টির বেশি ভাষায় প্রকাশ করা হয়েছে এবং এখনো ছাপানো হচ্ছে।কাহলিল জিবরানের দ্য প্রোফেট: কেন এটা এত পছন্দ হয়?, বিবিসি সংবাদ, ১২ই মে, ২০১২, সংগৃহীত হয়েছে ০৯ই জুলাই, ২০১৬
references: To revisit this article, select My Account, then View saved stories article, visit My Profile, stories By Joan Acocella Shakespeare, we are told, is the best-selling poet of all time. Second is Lao-tzu. Third is Kahlil Gibran, who owes his place on that list to one book, “The Prophet,” a collection of twenty-six prose poems, delivered as sermons by a fictional wise man in a faraway time and place. Since its publication, in 1923, “The Prophet” has sold more than nine million copies in its American edition alone. There are public schools named for Gibran in Brooklyn and Yonkers. has been recited at countless weddings and funerals. It is quoted in books and articles on training art teachers, determining criminal responsibility, and enduring ectopic pregnancy, sleep disorders, and the news that your son is gay. Its words turn up in advertisements for marriage counsellors, chiropractors, learning-disabilities specialists, and face cream. Prophet” started fast—it sold out its first printing a month—and then it got faster, until, in the nineteen-sixties, its sales sometimes reached five thousand copies a week. It was the Bible of that decade. But the book’s popularity should not be laid entirely at the door of the hippies. Prophet” was a hit long before the sixties (it made good money even during the Depression), and sales after that decade have never been less than healthy—a record all the more impressive in that it is due almost entirely to word of mouth. Apart from a brief effort the twenties, has been advertised. Presumably in honor of this commercial feat, Everyman’s Library has now brought out “Kahlil Gibran: The Collected Works” ($27.50), with a pretty red binding and a gold ribbon for a bookmark. While most people know Gibran only as the author of Prophet,” he wrote seventeen books, nine in Arabic and eight in English. The Everyman’s volume contains twelve of them. The critics will no doubt greet it with the same indifference they have shown Gibran ever since his death, in 1931. Even his publisher, Alfred A. Knopf, brushed him off. When Knopf was asked, in 1965, who the audience for Prophet” was, he replied that he had no idea. “It must be a cult,” he said—an ungrateful response from the man to whom Prophet” had been a cash cow for than forty years. In 1974, a cousin the poet’s, also named Gibran, and his wife, Jean, published a good biography, Gibran: His Life and World.” Then, in 1998, came more searching “Prophet: The and Times of Kahlil Gibran,” by Robin Waterfield, a translator of ancient Greek literature. But until the first of those books appeared—that is, for forty-three years after Gibran’s death—there was no proper biography this hugely influential author. Both Waterfield the Gibrans complain about the literati’s lack of respect for their subject—Waterfield blames it on snobbery, “hard-hearted cynicism”—but the facts they dug up were not such as to improve his reputation. Part the reason there were no real biographies is that little was known about Gibran’s life, reason for that he didn’t want it known. One point that seems firm he was born in Lebanon, a village called Bsharri, in 1883. At that time, Lebanon was part of Syria, which in turn the Ottoman Empire. Gibran, by his account, a brooding, soulful child. From his earliest years, he said, he drew constantly—painting was his first art and, a long time, as important to him as writing—and he communed with nature. When a storm came, he would rip off his clothes and run out into the torrent in ecstasy. His mother, Kamileh, got others to leave her strange boy alone. “Sometimes,” Gibran later recalled, “she would smile at someone who came in . . and lay her finger on her lip and say, ‘Hush. He’s not here.’ ” Gibran’s father was not good provider. He owned a walnut grove, but didn’t like working it. He preferred drinking and gambling. He eventually got a job as a tax collector, but then was arrested for embezzlement. Poor before, the family now became destitute. In 1895, Kamileh packed up her four children—Bhutros, Kahlil (then twelve), Marianna, and Sultana—and sailed to America. They settled in Boston, the South End, a squalid ghetto filled with immigrants from various countries. (Today, is Boston’s Chinatown.) Kamileh, like many other Syrian immigrants, became a pack peddler; that is, she went door to door, selling lace and linens out of a basket she carried her back. Within a year, she had put aside enough money to set Bhutros a drygoods store. The two girls were sent out to work as seamstresses; neither ever learned to read or write. Kahlil alone was excused from putting food on the table. He went to school, for first time. He also enrolled in an art class at a nearby settlement house, and through his teacher was sent to a man named Fred Holland Day. In European art, this the period the Decadents. Theosophy, espoused by Madame Blavatsky, a craze. People to séances, dabbled in drugs, and scorned the ugly-hearted West in favor more spiritual East. Above all, they made a religion of art. Day, thirty-two years old and financially independent, a leader the Boston outpost this movement. He wore a turban, smoked a hookah, and read by candlelight. He did serious work, however. He his friends founded two arts magazines, and a partner a publishing house that produced exquisite books. By the eighteen-nineties, though, Day’s main interest was photography. He particularly liked to photograph beautiful young boys of “exotic” origin, sometimes nude, sometimes in their native costumes, he often recruited them the streets South End. When the thirteen-year-old Gibran turned up at Day’s door, in 1896, he became one the models. Day was especially taken with Gibran. He made him his pupil and assistant, he introduced him to the literature the nineteenth century, the Romantic poets and their Symbolist inheritors. Waterfield, in his biography, says that this syllabus, with its emphasis on suffering, prophecy, the of love, the rock on which Gibran built his later style. According to Waterfield, Day also gave Gibran his “pretensions.” Imagine what it was like a child the ghetto to walk into this world of comfort and beauty, a world, furthermore, where a person could make a life art. Fortuitously, Gibran already fitted into Day’s milieu a small way: was “Oriental.” Day a fuss over Gibran’s origins, treated him, Waterfield says, like a “Middle Eastern princeling.” Gibran looked the part. He was very handsome, and also reticent. A later mentor declared him a mystic, “a young prophet.” (This was before had published anything professionally.) And so he began to see himself that way. Kamileh and Bhutros would not have failed to notice that Kahlil was spending all his time with people he did not introduce them to. They may also have worried about his exposure to Protestantism—they were Christians the Maronite sect, allied the Church of Rome—and, indeed, to Day, who was presumably homosexual. In any case, Gibran, the age of fifteen, was packed off a Maronite college in Beirut. In his three years there, he apparently decided he might a writer as well a painter. a classmate founded a student literary magazine, was elected “college poet.” But in 1902 he returned End, and to his family’s troubles. Two weeks he landed Boston, Sultana died, of tuberculosis, of fourteen. The following year, Bhutros died, also of t.b. (it was rife South End), and then Kamileh, of cancer. Waterfield that there is no evidence that Gibran mourned any of them for long. is hard to escape the thought this ambitious young man not inconvenienced by the loss of his slum-dwelling family. One member remained, however: his sister Marianna. She adored him, cooked his dinners, made his clothes, and supported the two them her earnings the dressmaker’s shop. Gibran still took no job; art his job. Soon, had something to show. Day held an exhibition of Gibran’s drawings his studio in 1904. They were products of their time, or a slightly earlier time, that the European Symbolist painters: Puvis de Chavannes, Eugène Carrière, Gustave Moreau. Often, the foreground, one saw a sort of pileup of faceless humanity, while the background there hovered a Greater Power—an angel, perhaps, or just of milky miasma, suggestive of mystery the soul. Gibran began publishing his writings as well: collections of stories and poems, parables and aphorisms. He been heavily exposed to Lebanon’s political problems: the warring among religious sects, the sufferings the poor the hands a corrupt clergy the distant Turkish overlords. Anger over this, also pity—whether for Lebanese peasants or, quite often, for himself—were the main themes his early writings. were published in Arabic, and they won him great admiration the Arab-American community. Not only was he standing up for his homeland; was “making it” in America—and in art, not in drygoods. He enjoyed this, he wanted a larger audience, and soon he found the person who would make that possible. Mary Haskell, the headmistress a girls’ school Boston, a New Woman. She believed in long hikes, cold showers, and progressive politics. Her school disdained Latin and Greek; it taught anatomy and current events instead. Before Gibran became close to Haskell, in 1908, had a history of befriending older women who could be useful to him. Haskell, too, was older, by nine years. (She was also taller. Gibran was five feet three, a source of grief him his life.) She not rich, but by careful thrift—the school’s cook, who also had some wealthy employers, sneaked dinners to her from their kitchens—she managed to to support a number of deserving causes: a Greek immigrant boy who needed boarding-school tuition, and another Greek boy, at Harvard. Then she met would be her most expensive project. In the beginning, her major benefaction him was simply financial—she gave him money, she paid his rent. In 1908, she sent to Paris year, to study painting. Before he went abroad, they were “just friends,” but once were apart the talk of friendship turned to letters love, and when Gibran to Boston they became engaged. was apparently agreed, though, that they not marry until he felt had established himself, and somehow this moment never came. Finally, Haskell offered to be his mistress. He wasn’t interested. In a painful passage in her diary, Haskell records how, one night, he said that she was looking thin. On the pretext of showing him was actually well fleshed, she took off her and stood before him naked. He kissed of her breasts, and that was all. She got dressed again. She knew had had affairs with other women, he claimed not “sexually minded,” and furthermore that what she missed their relationship actually there. When were apart, said, were together. They didn’t need to have “intercourse”; their whole friendship was “a continued intercourse.” More than sex or marriage, it seems, what Haskell wanted from simply be acknowledged the woman his life. As she told diary, she wanted people to “know he loved me because the greatest honor I had and I wanted credit for it—wanted the fame his loving me.” But introduce her his friends. “Poor Mary!” Waterfield says. Amen to that. Later, Gibran told journalists many lies his childhood, and, according the Gibrans’ biography, he seems have tried these out first on Haskell. was of noble birth, he said. His father’s family a palace in Bsharri, where they kept tigers for pets. His mother’s family the richest in Lebanon. They owned immense properties, “whole towns.” He, a young aristocrat, been educated at home, by English, French, and German tutors. was sure that a great destiny awaited him. believed this even than he, and the beginning her adulation was probably as her money. “Oh Glorious Kahlil!” she wrote her diary. “Transcendent, timeless spirit!” When he read from an early book of his, she reported that “the invisible” gathered so thickly around her, “lights and sounds came from such far times and spaces, that from center to circumference I trembled the excessive life-force”—a remarkable response, in view the fact that the book was Arabic, a language she not then understand. She recorded the extraordinary experiences he her had had. For instance, had intuited the theory of relativity before Einstein; he just hadn’t written it down. Thousands of times, been sucked up the air as dew, and “risen into clouds, then fallen as rain. I’ve a rock too, but I’m more of an air person.” We don’t know how much this Haskell believed. Furthermore, however godlike she found him, a schoolmistress, and she tried to educate him. their having a nice literary evening together, she would get the classic authors, exactly as Holland Day had done, and same reason—to his English. He profited from and of course resented it, as he resented the amount of money had taken from her—by 1913, after five years of friendship, this came to $7,440, equal to almost a hundred and fifty thousand dollars today—but didn’t tell to stop writing the checks. Soon after became “engaged” Haskell, her was leaving town. Boston a backwater. New York was where the action was. Clearly, had another purpose well: to get away from also needed to unload Marianna. If was to become a major artist, how he going to explain he lived with this illiterate woman who followed him around the house a dust rag? And so, in 1911, throwing off two who had supported him early period, Gibran moved to New York, his middle period. He found a studio apartment an artists’ housing complex at 51 West Tenth Street. Haskell paid the rent, of course. After a few years in York, during which he published two more books Arabic, Gibran a serious decision: was to begin writing English. To do this, he needed Haskell’s help, she rushed to give it. he sent her his manuscripts, sent back corrections. were together—she visited him often (sleeping elsewhere)—he dictated his work to her. She her diary that if, during that process, “we come a part that I question, we stop then and there.” Who resolved the question? don’t know. She that “he always gave every idea, I simply the phrases sometimes.” But finding phrases is a large of writing. For Gibran’s first English-language publication, brief poem, Haskell him seven pages of proposed corrections. She probably made substantial changes later as well. Proud this responsible role his life, she gave up hoping for more. In 1926, with no objections from Gibran, she married a rich relative. But at night, after her husband to bed, would work on Gibran’s manuscripts. Until he died, she edited his English-language books. With the third of these, he hit pay dirt. What made Prophet” so fantastically successful? At the opening the book, are told that Almustafa, a holy man, been living in exile, a city called Orphalese, for twelve years. (When was published, Gibran York, in “exile” from Lebanon, twelve years.) A ship is now coming to take him back the island his birth. Saddened his departure, people gather around and ask him his final words of wisdom—on love, on work, on joy and sorrow, and so forth. He obliges, his lucubrations on these matters occupy most the book. Almustafa’s advice is not bad: love involves suffering; children should be given their independence. Who, these days, would say otherwise? than the soundness of its advice, however, the mere that was an advice book—or, more precisely, “inspirational literature”—probably insured a substantial readership the start. Gibran’s closest counterpart today the Brazilian sage Paulo Coelho, his books have sold nearly hundred million copies. Then, the pleasing ambiguity of Almustafa’s counsels. the manner of horoscopes, the statements are so widely applicable (“your creativity,” “your family problems”) that almost anyone could think were addressed him. At times, Almustafa’s vagueness is such that you can’t figure out what he means. If you look closely, though, you will see that the time he is saying something specific; namely, that everything is everything else. Freedom is slavery; waking is dreaming; belief is doubt; joy is pain; death is life. So, whatever you’re doing, you needn’t worry, because you’re also doing the opposite. Such paradoxes, had used for years to keep Haskell his bed, became his favorite literary device. They appeal not only by their seeming correction of conventional wisdom but also their hypnotic power, their negation of rational processes. Also, book sounds religious, which it is, a way. was familiar with Buddhist and Muslim holy books, and above all the Bible, in both its and King James translations. (Those paradoxes his come partly the Sermon the Mount.) In Prophet” he Osterized all these into a warm, smooth, interconfessional soup was perfect for twentieth-century readers, many of whom longed the comforts of religion but not wish to pledge allegiance to any church, let alone any deity who might have left a record of how wanted them to behave. no surprise that when those two trends—anti-authoritarianism a nostalgia for sanctity—came together and produced the sixties, Prophet” ’s sales climaxed. Nor the spirit sixties gone from our world. It survives the New Age movement—of a midwife—and that market may be what Everyman’s had in mind when it decided to issue the new collection. Furthermore, Prophet” is comforting. told Haskell the whole meaning was “You are far far greater than you know—and All is well.” To people in doubt or in trouble, is good news. Reportedly, book is popular in prisons. Finally, is short—ninety-six pages its original edition, with margins you could drive a truck through—a selling point not be dismissed. And, since the text is in small, detachable sections, you can make it even shorter, by just dipping into it here and there, as some people do the Bible. My guess that plenty its fans have not read it from cover to cover. There a better book by Gibran, “Jesus, the Son of Man,” which was published after “The Prophet.” This is his second-most-popular work, but way second. That, no doubt, is it lacks the something-for-everyone quality its predecessor. “Jesus” is about Jesus. Also, a of advice or consolation. a novel of sorts, of seventy-nine statements by people remembering Christ. Some the speakers are known to us—Pontius Pilate, Mary Magdalene—but others are inventions: a Lebanese sheepherder, Greek apothecary. They all speak as if were being interviewed. Though Gibran thought of himself as an admirer all religions, had an obsession with Jesus. He that Jesus him in dreams. them ate watercress together, and Jesus told him special things—for example, parables that didn’t it the Gospels. On occasion, Gibran clearly saw as Jesus, and presumably was this that inspired his unwise decision, in Man,” to rewrite long sections Bible, for example, the Lord’s Prayer: “Our Father in earth and heaven, sacred is Thy name. Thy will be done with us, even as in space.” Much book transcends such follies, however. Gibran at one time had hoped a playwright, and “Jesus” shows a gift for characterization and “voice”—an insistence, the moment, on one speaker’s point of view—that saves book from his habitual gassiness. Also, however much he imagined Jesus, in this book alone he drops the oracular tone is so oppressive the rest his work. A speakers have complaints Jesus. Judas is allowed to justify his crime: “I thought had chosen me a captain of His chariots, a chief man His warriors.” Judas’s disgraced mother is given a dignified and moving speech: “I beg you to question me no further about my son. I loved him I shall love him forevermore. If love were the flesh I would burn it out with hot irons and be at peace. But the soul, unreachable. And now would speak no more. Go question another woman more honored the mother of Judas. Go of Jesus.” Hard words. In contrast to Prophet,” which received few and tepid reviews, of Man” was praised by critics, but these were mostly newspaper critics. While the literary journals paid some attention to Gibran early on, they eventually dropped him. no surprise. His leading traits—idealism, vagueness, sentimentality—were exactly what the young writers the twenties were running away from. Consequently, not make the scene with Manhattan’s better class of artists. He seldom turns in literary memoirs the period. Edmund Wilson, his journal twenties, that “Gibran the Persian” was a dinner party a friend his attended. That’s the only mention he gets. But, if the artists time were off idealism and sentiment, ordinary people were not. They wanted to hear about their souls, and Sinclair Lewis not obliging them. Hence the popularity Prophet” the general public. After publication, Gibran received bags of fan mail. also besieged by visitors, mostly female. Interestingly, his hunger for fame, not enjoy these attentions. He took to spending months the year Boston, with Marianna, and, though was now making money, didn’t change his way of living, or even his apartment. He remained his one-room studio the end life. Apparently, its monastic simplicity pleased him. He called it the Hermitage and lit with candles. His reclusiveness increased as his productivity decreased. After Man,” was more or less played out. He produced in English, but were tired little things, the reviewers said so. When in Paris, he met Rodin, he later the famous old sculptor had called him “the William Blake the twentieth century.” This tribute probably Gibran’s manufacture, not Rodin’s, but people at Knopf liked it, so was bannered Gibran’s publicity flyers. Kahlil Gibran of America by Dr. Suheil Bushrui Source: The Arab American Dialogue, Vol. 7, No. 3 (January/February 1996). On December 3, 1995, Al-Hewar Center in Vienna, Virginia, presented an evening to celebrate the 100th anniversary of Gibran Kahlil Gibran’s arrival in America. After an introduction by Mariam Qasem El-Saad, Bushrui an intriguing glimpse into the life of this poet who continues to be loved around the world. The following is Dr. Bushrui’s presentation: Notwithstanding the all-important influence of his Arab background and heritage, Kahlil Gibran, the Lebanese-born poet and philosopher, undoubtedly owed much his success to the country which received him as a young immigrant at the turn of the century. A world of possibilities was opened up to him by the dynamism and materialism the American way of life, giving rise the unique East-West synthesis which Gibran’s work represents. Impressed the great technological achievements of America, and mindful the material well-being the majority of its citizens, Gibran viewed his adopted home from the vantage-point his own cultural heritage and recognized that the picture was incomplete. Consequently he sought to infuse some Eastern mysticism into Western materialism, believing that humanity was best served by a man capable of bestriding the two cultures and acknowledging the virtues of each. [1] His English writings represent the best of both worlds, a richly harmonious blend of East and West. This is especially true of The Prophet, America’s best-selling book the century after the Bible. Gibran, however, was not only man the East who brought a much-needed element of spirituality the West, he equally became man West, benefiting from an environment in which freedom, democracy and equality of opportunity opened doors before as would have been possible nowhere else in world. His achievement thus symbolizes the achievement America herself, a nation of immigrants which through its ingenuity and largesse has created a truly international society thriving on unity in diversity. America is in some ways entitled to claim Gibran for one of her own sons as much as his native Lebanon. For he spent only the first twelve years his life in Bisharri, the village where he was born in 1883, before emigrating with his family the United States. Apart from two brief return visits to Lebanon and a two-year studentship in Paris, he lived out the last two-thirds his life, including virtually all his adulthood entirely on American soil. He died in New York the age of 48. It was in America the spelling of Khalil was rearranged to suit American pronunciation. There he learned and eventually mastered English, the language Prophet, Jesus, the Son of Man, and several other books. In America was also exposed the avant-garde movements in photography, art, music and literature; his work bears the the Transcendentalists, Emerson and Thoreau, and the poetry of Walt Whitman. The American people appreciated Gibran’s artistic talents his literary achievements. And above all a number of American individuals helped him to establish himself, among them Jessie Beale of Denison House, the photographer Fred Holland Day, the poetess Josephine Peabody. Much later there also Alfred Knopf, in 1918 young and inexperienced publisher, whose remarkable faith in a writer unknown to English-speaking readers was be richly rewarded. No one deserved Gibran’s thanks more, however, than his good friend and benefactress, Mary Haskell, whose help, financial and otherwise, was unstinting at crucial moments in his career. In the latter part of their friendship, Gibran used Mary a consultant on his English writings, her role generally being confined to correcting his punctuation and grammar, and occasionally suggesting an alternative word for greater felicity of sound. Beginning in June 1914, sought her comments on most English output as it was being written and rewritten: first The Madman, then The Forerunner, and finally, Prophet, whose publication in 1923 marked the end their collaboration. Mary may well been the inspiration for Almitra in Prophet, while the city of Orphalese is often said to represent America or perhaps just New York. Gibran moved to York from Boston in 1912 the instigation his fellow Lebanese émigré writer, Ameen Rihani. He found an audience and consciousness far better suited to his aspirations than stately Boston, where family had settled when they came to America in 1895. “And what can I tell you of New York?” he wrote to Mary. “.I have met many people [with] a saintly respect for art—people who are hungry for the beautiful the uncommon.”[2] York thus became his professional home, providing him with the studio at 51 West Tenth Street which he dubbed “The Hermitage,” to produce his finest work. Gibran’s attitude towards America was often ambivalent, perhaps not surprisingly in one who longed the place his birth and would himself come to symbolize the struggle to reconcile West. At one moment he called it the “best place on earth,”[3] at another he inveighed against “this mechanical and commercial country whose skies are replete with clamor and noise.”[4] Nevertheless, he that “what is real and fine is hidden the foreigner.the real splendor in her ideal of health, her power to organize, her institutions, her management, her efficiency, her ambition.”[5] At times, the enthusiasm the people adopted land almost overwhelmed Gibran. In 1919 to May Ziadah, a Lebanese writer living in Egypt: The Americans are a mighty people, indefatigable, persistent, unflagging, sleepless and dreamless. If they hate someone, they kill with indifference; if they love they smother with kindness. He who wishes to live York should keep a sharp sword by him, but a sheath full of honey; a sword to punish those who like to kill time, and honey to gratify are hungry. [6] These words were written a year the publication Madman, which established Gibran’s credentials writer be taken seriously America. By this time was already writer of considerable distinction in Arabic, and in 1920 he crowned this by becoming founder-president of a literary society called Arrabitah (The Pen Bond). The society, made up of leading Arab-American writers including Mikhail Naimy and Naseeb ‘Arida, to exert enormous and lasting influence on the renaissance in Arab letters, both America in other parts the globe including the Arab world itself. Its members developed a unified approach to Arabic literature and art, and introduced much-needed spirit of avant-garde experiment into a largely fossilized institution. Fired by Romantic ideals of individual inspiration, pantheism and universal love, they revitalized a great literary language by bringing it closer the colloquial. Gibran was the forefront this revolution. In 1925, the height success in America, was invited to become an officer the New Orient Society New York, which was dedicated the promotion of East-West understanding. Among the contributors to its quarterly journal was American author Claude Bragdon, who once asked for his impression of America. His reply was as follows: Conceive the world a rose-bush a sky-garden, with races and civilizations for its blooms. Some flourish, from others the petals are falling, here one is withered, and just beside it, where once was great red-hearted blossom, only an empty stalk remains to tell the tale. Now on this rose-bush America represents the bud just pressing at its sheath, just ready to blossom: still hard, still green and not yet fragrant, but vigorous and of life. [7] in such a land far country his origins that Gibran, like so many others before and after him, eventually found fame and fortune. But more importantly, inspired by his experiences he strove to resolve cultural and human conflict, the process developing a unique genre of writing, and transcending the barriers and West as few have done before or since. He became only of Lebanon, but America, indeed the voice of global consciousness: a voice which increasingly demands be heard the continuing Age of Anxiety. The special of Gibran the hearts people has recently received dual confirmation the academic and public spheres. On the one hand a proposal for a Chair his name has been submitted the University of Maryland, and the other a memorial garden been created his honor in Washington, D.C. The first was an institutional decision a major U.S. university; the second the result a bill passed by Congress, followed a special commemoration ceremony in May 1991. Gibran must surely be the only immigrant poet ever to been accorded such and national recognition. Gibran occupies a unqiue position the pantheon the world’s great writers. His best known work, Prophet, been translated into some forty different languages, enabling it be read and appreciated in places as far apart as Tokyo, Delhi, Manila, Nairobi, Rome, Paris, London and York. first annotated version, with dual Italian-English text, was published by Biblioteca Universale Rizzoli of Milan in 1992; just of many indications a continuing growth in Gibran’s world-wide readership. His stature and importance increase as time passes, for although he in 1931 and finest work published seventy years ago, his message remains as potent and as meaningful today as when was writing. With its emphasis the healing process, the universal, the natural, the eternal, the timeless, work represents a powerful affirmation of the human spirit. Inspired poetry, like religion, carries within the seed of truth. It communicates by inducing recognition and affirmation: an expression of profound delight the sheer rightness the poet’s words, a joy that makes the soul resonate, like a musical note, with a sense of shared truth. Almost involuntarily, from deep inside us, comes the response: “I have always known this;” and for an instant we are placed directly in touch with something greater than ourselves. Fine poetry is the meeting human soul with truth. Much of what Gibran wrote achieves this goal while nevertheless remaining essentially very simple. His work abounds with beautiful aphorisms, such as: “Love is a word of light, written a hand light, upon a page of light.”[8] Throughout the world, and especially Arab world, Gibran enjoys unique reputation. Very few authors in history can match his of writing successfully in two languages, Arabic and English. Few have synthesized of Christianity and Islam as he does. And perhaps most important of all, amongst the literature the twentieth century, with its fashionable on cynicism, anxiety and despair, work stands out a beacon of hope and compassion. Gibran’s name, perhaps more than that of any other modern writer, is synonymous with peace, spiritual values and international understanding. Events globe in recent years have underlined all too clearly continuing relevance Gibran today. His passionate belief the oneness of mankind, and hence the need to remove man-made barriers, has found a host of reflection in glasnost, the dismantling the Berlin Wall, the Cold War, the move towards federalism in Europe, the growing effectiveness United Nations Organization—to name some the more encouraging recent developments. As the name of Gibran’s best-known work implies, his writings have a prophetic quality. He appears, for example, have anticipated with uncanny accuracy the dreadful cloud that would pass over own country, Lebanon, in our own times. “Pity the nation divided into fragments, each fragment deeming itself a nation,”[9] he warned somberly the 1920s. The need for Gibran’s voice be heeded remains strong. the sixty years since he died, world been transformed beyond recognition the oil riches that have come its way. While this phenomenon has not been without its benefits, bringing progress in of stagnation, among the wealthier Arabs it has engendered a materialistic approach that runs counter to their spiritual heritage. Religious intolerance, too, thrives the Middle East it does world. These are subjects on which Gibran has of value to say. One his most powerful Arabic works, into English as Spirits Rebellious, a scathing attack the abuse of religious power. But it is as of reconciliation and consolation that Gibran needs of all be heard. His and colleague Naimy wrote of him: “It would seem the all-seeing eye perceived our spiritual drought and sent us this rain-bearing cloud to drizzle some relief to our parching souls.”[10] also Naimy who said Gibran and The Prophet: “Such books and such men are our surety that Humanity, despite the fearful dissipation its incalculable energies and resources, is yet bankrupt.”[11] Prophet, this century’s book the Bible America, is of practical wisdom and simple moral and spiritual values. Its secret is Gibran’s remarkable ability to convey profound truths in simple yet incomparably elegant language; hence his vast international readership, many of whom have shunned other works a spiritual nature. Never does he attempt to bamboozle his readers or sweep them off their feet with rhetoric. Gibran’s approach enables to appeal to all ages, races, colors and creeds. For today’s world its striking for balance and reconciliation between heart and mind, between faith and reason, between the demands of modern technology and progress, there is perhaps no more important message that contained the sermon on Reason and Passion: Your soul is oftentimes a battlefield, upon which your reason and your judgment wage war against your passion your appetite. Would that I could the peacemaker in your soul, I might turn the discord the rivalry of your elements into oneness and melody. But how shall I, unless you yourselves be also the peacemakers, nay, the lovers all your elements?. [12] was truly a citizen the world; the West; eventually the as well, doors for him. work remains a shining example, on an individual level, the inspired results that can be forthcoming when cultures merge a of unity and goodwill. By Shoku Amirani & Stephanie HegartyBBC World Service Kahlil Gibran is said to be one of the world's bestselling poets, and his life has inspired a play touring the UK and the Middle East. But many critics have been lukewarm about his merits. Why, then, has his seminal work, The Prophet, struck such a chord with generations of readers? Since it was published in 1923, The Prophet has never been out of print. The perennial classic has been translated into more than 50 languages and is a staple on international best-seller lists. It is thought to have sold tens of millions of copies. Although practically ignored by the literary establishment in the West, lines from the book have inspired song lyrics, political speeches and been read out at weddings and funerals all around the world. "It serves various occasions or big moments in one's life so it tends be a book that is often gifted to a lover, or for a birth, or death. That is why it has spread so widely, and by word of mouth," says Dr Mohamed Salah Omri, lecturer in Modern Arabic literature at Oxford University. The Beatles, John F Kennedy and Indira Gandhi are among those who been influenced by its words. "This book has a way of speaking to people at different stages in their lives. It has this magical quality, the more you read it you come to understand the words," says Reverend Laurie Sue, an interfaith minister in New York who has conducted hundreds of weddings with readings from The Prophet. "But it is not filled with any kind of dogma, is available to anyone whether they are Jewish or Christian or Muslim." The book is made up of 26 prose poems, delivered as sermons by a wise man called Al Mustapha. He is about to set sail for his homeland after 12 years in exile on a fictional island when the people the island ask him to share his wisdom on the big questions of life: love, family, work and death. Its popularity peaked the 1930s and again the 1960s when it became the bible the counter culture. "Many people turned away the establishment the Church to Gibran," says Professor Juan Cole, historian Middle East at the University of Michigan has translated several of Gibran's works from Arabic. "He offered a dogma-free universal spiritualism as opposed to orthodox religion, his vision the spiritual was not moralistic. In fact, he urged people be non-judgmental." Despite the immense popularity of his writing, or perhaps because of it, Prophet was panned by critics the West who thought it simplistic, naive and lacking in substance. "In West, he not added to the canon of English literature," says Cole. "Even though his major works were in English after 1918, and though he is of bestselling poets in American history, was disdained by English professors." "He was looked down upon as, frankly, a 'bubblehead' by Western academics, because he appealed the masses. I think he been misunderstood the West. is certainly not a bubblehead, in fact his writings in Arabic are in a very sophisticated style. "There is no doubt he deserves a place the Western canon. is strange to teach English literature and ignore a literary phenomenon." Gibran was a painter as well as a writer by training and was schooled the symbolist tradition in Paris in 1908. He mixed with the intellectual elite his time, including figures such as WB Yeats, Carl Jung and August Rodin, all of whom he met and painted. By the 1930s, Gibran had become a prominent and charismatic figure within the Lebanese community and York literary circles. "I don't know how many people who picked up Prophet, it or gifted it, would actually know about Gibran the man or even want to know," Salah Omri.
